ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Push and Pull and learned that everything needs a push or a pull to get moving—even people!
In this activity, we’ll look at pictures of different things that are moving, and sort them into two groups:

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Push group is for objects that need a push for them to move.
Pull group is for objects that need a pull for them to move.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach/Model Introduce the first picture card. Encourage children to place the picture card of the child with the tractor in the “Push” group.
Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Discuss with children whether the object belongs in the “Push” or “Pull” pile and give it to a child to place in the right location.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In Push and Pull, we learned how everything moves by giving it a push or a pull. Let’s look at more of the things we move every day and decide if we push or pull them to make them move. We can start in the morning with our toothbrush. How do you move your toothbrush? What else do you move every morning? Who can name three objects you can push? Who can name three objects you can pull?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Before you begin, review each picture card with children. Show children pushing a toy car, pulling a wagon, opening a refrigerator door, picking flowers, and pushing someone on a swing. Have children pantomime pushing and pulling to open a door.

Have children name classroom objects that need a push to move and objects that need a pull to move. Then have them name and demonstrate how many objects (e.g., toy cars, balls) can be pushed versus pulled.

Use the picture cards to help develop multilingual learners’ oral language and vocabulary. Encourage children to name as many things as possible in each picture. For example, they can describe what the people are wearing and how many people they see in each picture, along with any colors they can identify. Repeat what children have said in complete sentences and encourage them to repeat the sentence after you. For example, “Very good. There are two children in this picture. Can you say that?”
Have children repeat the actions of pushing or pulling the various objects as a group. Encourage them to exaggerate the gestures of pushing and pulling.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Set up a toy car area in your room with materials that children can use to make simple ramps and obstacles for their cars.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Push and Pull and learned how our actions can affect how things move.
You’ll each take a toy car and go over to our car area and see all the different ways we can make it move.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explore Movement Ask children to see how many different ways they can move the cars. Make sure they try out how a ramp affects the toy cars’ movements. Try and have children experiment with different ramp surfaces to notice the impact of friction on the cars’ speed. Have them note what happens when their cars hit obstacles (e.g., other cars, other objects, their hands). What can they do to make their cars go faster? What can they do to slow them down? What can they do to stop them?

Talk About Movement What happens when we push the car very hard? When we push it just a little bit? When we send the car down the ramp? Stop it with our hand? Work together with children to come up with a list of how they speed up and slowed down their cars, how they stopped their cars, and how they made their cars change direction. Encourage children to talk about the connection between their actions and their cars’ movements.

For children who are developmentally delayed, pair them with a partner who is more comfortable making the toy cars move in different ways. Have that child show their partner how they moved their car, and help their partner to do the same thing.

Ask children to summarize what they learned and the connections they made in complete sentences. For example: When I pushed my car down the ramp, the car went faster. When I made my car crash into another car, both cars changed directions.

Learning is transferable across languages. So, if children learn the principles of motion, pushing, and pulling in one language, they will easily transfer that learning to another language. Therefore, if children prefer to do this activity in their home language with other children who share the same home language, what they discover and learn about movement will easily transfer to English. It is just a matter of learning new labels or words to express the same concepts.

Depending on the number of children playing with their cars at the same time, there will be a lot going on in the play area. Encourage children to focus on their own cars, making sure they take note of the color and any other distinguishing features of their cars.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book Push and Pull and learned how things move in different ways. We also learned how we can speed up or slow down different objects.

In this activity, we’ll look at pictures of different people, animals, and objects as they move and talk about which ones go fast and which ones go slow. Then we will put the pictures into two groups: fast and slow.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show one picture card and ask the questions on the back of the card, offering extra challenge and support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to line up in the “Slow” or the “Fast” column.
Repeat Continue the activity with the next card.

Talk About Speed Discuss with children what they learned in Push and Pull about how we can make some things go faster or slower. Remind them of what friction is and how it works to slow things down. Invite children to talk about how the speed of something changes when we push or pull it.

Before you begin, make sure that children understand what it means for something to move fast or slow. Give everyday examples of objects that move fast and slow. That will help children better understand the activity.

Encourage children to participate in peer-to-peer conversations about fast and slow, with each child taking two turns in the conversation. Remind children that while one person is talking, the other is listening. The talker should hold the card as a reminder of this.

Invite multilingual learners to teach the class how to say fast and slow in their home language. In Spanish, these words are: fast (rápido) and slow (despacio). Have those children say the words slowly for children who are not familiar.

Invite children to use their bodies to show different speeds. Guide them to create various fast and slow movements with their bodies. You can have children do jumping jacks, move their arms in circles, or you can put yarn down on the floor to create a line and have children walk fast or slow down the line.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the poster called The Great Big Enormous Yuca and saw how the old man could not pull the yuca plant out of the ground by himself. He needed help.
Today we’re going to look at some pictures and sort the pictures into two groups: objects we can move and objects we cannot move.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach/Model When you show each card, ask children to give a thumbs-up if they think the picture shows something they could move, or a thumbs-down if it shows something they could not move.
Ask Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Moving Objects Discuss the objects that the children say they are not able to move. Ask what they might do to be able to move these objects. Remind children of how the old man was able to move the yuca with help from others. Allow children to come up with creative ways for how they might move the objects. Are there any machines that they know of that could be used to help them move these objects? Can people help?

For younger or developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Then, ask children to tell what else they know about what they see in the picture. Encourage as much conversation as possible.
Have children brainstorm a list of objects in the classroom that might be hard to move by themselves, and ways that they might be able to move them.

For Spanish speakers, the word elephant (elefante) is a cognate. Some Spanish speakers call a sandwich, “sándwich.” Invite multilingual learners to teach the rest of the class how to say book in their home language. They may then want to teach the class how to say a big book and a small book.
Encourage children to think of creative solutions for how to move the big objects they saw in the pictures. Have them show their drawings to others and explain their solutions.
